intro: Allium bourgeaui, commonly known as the Corsican leek, is a perennial bulbous plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its slender, grass-like leaves and small, clustered white or pale pink flowers. The plant produces edible bulbs that are similar in taste to leeks, making it a valuable culinary crop. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, often growing in rocky or coastal areas. Due to its ornamental value and edible qualities, it is cultivated in gardens and traditional cuisines across its native range.
